email.title: Final Reading Group this FRIDAY - An Introduction to WebAssembly (WASM)
email.text:
Hey everyone,
After a very successful year of holding Reading Groups, time has come for the final one, carried out by Philippa Gardner and Conrad Watt. The topic will be "An Introduction to WebAssembly" and we kindly invite you to **Huxley 218 this Friday at 1PM**.
email.heading: Reading Group by Philippa Gardner and Conrad Watt

event.text:
An Introduction to WebAssembly
WebAssembly (Wasm) is a stack-based, statically typed byte code language. It is the first new language to be natively supported on the Web in nearly 25 years, following JavaScript. Interestingly, the Wasm standard is written as a small-step operational semantics (remember your Models of Computation course!) with changes and extensions only permitted if they are formalised. Two of the key people formalising the Wasm standard are Andreas Rossberg, one of the originators of Wasm, and Conrad Watt, a current PhD student at Cambridge and a former Imperial student, who has done a mechanised specification of Wasm in Isabelle/HOL.
For this Reading Group, please read the main paper on Wasm: https://bit.ly/2PERozu
Bringing the Web up to Speed with WebAssembly, PLDIâ€™17, written by people at Google (including Rossberg, now at DFINITY), Mozilla, Microsoft and Apple.
We will give the historical context of the paper, lead a discussion on Wasm, and describe current and possible future roles of formal (even mechanised) specification of language standards.
